column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0020] The suitable average particle size of the carbon material, particularly the platelet material, is under 500 .mu.m, preferably in a range between 0.1 and 300 .mu.m, and particularly in a range between 0.1 and 100 .mu.m.
#Text=Particle size refers to the agglomeration-free primary particle.
#Text=The mass % of carbon material is advantageously less than 45% in the moldable blend.
#Text=Mass percents in the range between 2 and 35% are particularly preferred.
#Text=[0021] The molding of the moldable material according to step c) usually occurs in a press, with it being possible to cure the material thermally or catalytically.
#Text=Other pressure molding methods can also be used, depending on the consistency of the material.
#Text=The addition of expanded graphite, in particular, leads to a relatively good sliding and flowing capability, so that injection molding or related molding techniques can also be carried out.
#Text=[0022] In step d), the resulting green body is baked (i.e. carbonized) at temperatures between 750 and 1200.degree.
#Text=C. in the absence of air in order to produce the carbonaceous porous prebody (C/C body).
#Text=During this process, the bonding resin is broken down into carbon.
#Text=The carbonization may also be carried out at temperatures near 2400.degree.
#Text=C.
#Text=At these temperatures, the graphiting of carbon that has not yet been graphited occurs.
#Text=[0023] In the final step e), the C/C body is infiltrated with a silicon melt according to the conventional technique, preferably through the use of wicks.
#Text=At least part of the carbon of the C/C body is converted into SiC.
#Text=A ceramic composite material with a matrix composed predominantly of SiC is thereby formed.
#Text=Residual silicon and residual carbon occur in the ceramic composite material as additional matrix components.
#Text=When expanded graphite is used as the preferred added carbon material, a relatively low residual silicon content can be set.
#Text=The proportion of free silicon (residual silicon) in the ceramic composite material according to the invention is thus advantageously under 10% by mass.
#Text=In the case of an application as an anti-ballistic material or as a component of armor plating, the mass % of Si is preferably set at less than 7%.
#Text=High SiC contents can be achieved in correspondence to the low residual silicon content.
#Text=The proportion of SiC in the ceramic composite material is advantageously more than 60% by mass.
#Text=A high SiC content is important particularly in anti-ballistic applications.
#Text=In this case, the proportion of SiC is preferably above 70% by mass.

#Text=[0024] Beyond this, other metals besides silicon can be present in the silicon melt that is provided for the infiltration, such as Fe, Cr, W or Mo, the proportion of which in the melt typically does not exceed 20%.
#Text=Ti is particularly preferred as an additional carbide forming metal.
#Text=Silicon is also characterized as a metal in the context of this application.
#Text=The ceramic composite material that is produced with the method according to the invention has a density of over 2.5 g/cm.sup.3.
#Text=This value refers to infiltration with pure silicon.
#Text=When silicon alloys containing metals of greater or lesser density than silicon are used, these density ranges must be adapted according to the theoretical values.
#Text=The open porosity of the fiber-reinforced ceramic composite material is under 5% and the elongation at break is greater than 0.3%.

#Text=The composite material that is produced by the method according to the invention thus advantageously combines a high material density (i.e. low porosity) with a relatively high elongation at break.
